In paraconsistent logic, a statement can be both true and false simultaneously. To determine the truth value of the statement q = (p AND NOT p), we need to consider the possible truth values of p and NOT p.

Since p is both true and false, we can represent its truth value as (T, F). The truth value of NOT p would be the opposite, which is (F, T).

Now, we can evaluate the statement q = (p AND NOT p) using these truth values. In paraconsistent logic, the AND operator is evaluated as follows:

(T, F) AND (F, T) = (T*F, F*T) = (F, F)

So, the truth value of the statement q = (p AND NOT p) in paraconsistent logic is (F, F), which means it is false.
